rev.comment: /* Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia */
rev.diff:
Line 4: Line 4:
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person, usually in the context of a [[romantic love|romantic]] or interpersonal relationship; the accusation is that the person is so interpersonally controlling as to be better-suited to relationships with nonresponsive people.{{fact}}
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person, usually in the context of a [[romantic love|romantic]] or interpersonal relationship; the accusation is that the person is so interpersonally controlling as to be better-suited to relationships with nonresponsive people.{{fact}}
â
==Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia==
+
==Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia(Oh, you so crazy)==
â
===Cause and prevalance (Oh, you so crazy)===
+
===Cause and prevalance===
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> (1958) commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic fantasies may occur more often than is generally supposed.
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> (1958) commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic fantasies may occur more often than is generally supposed.
